(5) (How) does AI affect APIs?



APIs and AI: It's complicated Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(6) Let's See Where We Are… ✋

  1. Who has all/most/many APIs described with OpenAPI/AsyncAPI?
  2. Who has a central API catalog or portal?
  3. Who can track every API call with full observability?
  4. Who has sandbox environments with synthetic data?
  5. Who has AI agents working with APIs in production?
  • Don't worry if you didn't raise your hand much
  • Start with the basics, build incrementally


APIs and AI: It's complicated Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(7) The API Landscape Lifecycle

  • Not about single APIs → It's about the API landscape
  • Lifecycle of evolving towards AI readiness
    1. Step #1: More Tools [Step #1: More Tools (1)]
    2. Step #2: Better Described Tools [Step #2: Better Described Tools (1)]
    3. Step #3: Dynamic Tool Discovery [Step #3: Dynamic Tool Discovery (1)]
    4. Step #4: Workflow-Based Tools [Step #4: Workflow-Based Tools (1)]
    5. Step #5: Safe Tool Practices [Step #5: Safe Tool Practices (1)]


APIs and AI: It's complicated Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(8) Bridging the Gap Between API Land and AI Land

  • API landscapes are not AI-ready yet
  • Descriptions and designs often make AI difficult
  • Letting AI agents loose oftentimes is not an option
    • Limit blast radius: Only provide access through a centralized access point
    • Zero tolerance: Never allow access to production APIs
  • Use AI as much as necessary but as little as possible

(10) Why More APIs Matter



Step #1: More Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(11) More Tools



Step #1: More Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(12) Model Context Protocol (MCP)

  • MCP is the current standard protocol for LLM consumers
  • The initial focus was on additional and extended context
    • Additional context by providing access to the environment
    • Extended context by allowing MCP servers to externally manage context
  • Many mapping tools generate MCP servers from OpenAPI descriptions
  • What to expose and how to design it is out of scope


Step #1: More Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(13) MCP all the APIs

  1. Generate MCP from OpenAPI
  2. Publish/Install MCP servers for all APIs
  3. Consumers can access all MCP tools


Step #1: More Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(14) MCP all the APIs: Easy but Limited

  • Pros:
    • Zero development effort, many tools auto-generate MCP
    • All APIs easily available
    • Great for early and quick experimentation
  • Cons:
    • Context window explosion with large APIs
    • AI struggles with understanding workflow across endpoints
    • Risk of misinterpreting MCP problems as general AI problems
  • Good as a starting point but lacks sophistication and scalability


Step #1: More Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(15) MCP Solves Everything!?

  • Problem #1: Complex APIs will overload the MCP client's context
  • Problem #2: Larger API landscapes will overload the MCP client's context
  • Problem #3: Poor API design translates to poor MCP results
  • Problem #4: Bad AX results in unsatisfactory AI results


Step #1: More Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(16) More Tools ⇏ Better Tool Landscape

  • LLMs can now access many tools
  • But they cannot understand many of them well
  • Poor descriptions → poor tool selection → poor results
  • Next: Step #2: Better Described Tools [Step #2: Better Described Tools (1)]

(18) Better Described Tools



Step #2: Better Described Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(19) Do Your DX Homework

  • Most API descriptions need quality improvements anyway
  • Better descriptions benefit everyone, not just AI agents
    • Complete and meaningful operation summaries
    • Comprehensive examples for all operations
    • Clear error handling
    • Consistent terminology and naming
  • Good DX is the foundation for good AX


Step #2: Better Described Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(20) Now There's AX Homework, Too

  • AI agents need information developers don't typically require:
    • Everything that developers usually just know
    • Treat every API like an external one for developers with no context
  • OpenAPI Initiative (OAI) might add AX-specific fields
  • Until then, leverage description fields strategically


Step #2: Better Described Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(21) The OpenAPI Initiative (OAI)

  • Today: no AX-specific fields in OpenAPI (3.2)
  • Community needs to define what AI agents need (3.3)
  • Tooling will follow once fields are standardized
  • Interested? Join the discussion in the OpenAPI Initiative [https://openapis.org]!


Step #2: Better Described Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(22) API AI Readiness Score for APIs



Step #2: Better Described Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(23) Better Descriptions ⇏ Scalable Tool Use

  • Better AX reduces confusion and misuse
  • But even well-described tools still overload agent context
  • The problem shifts from understanding tools to finding the right ones
  • Next: Step #3: Dynamic Tool Discovery [Step #3: Dynamic Tool Discovery (1)]

(25) Dynamic Tool Discovery

(26) Anthropic Advanced Tool Use

Source: "Introducing advanced tool use on the Claude Developer Platform", November 24, 2025



Step #3: Dynamic Tool Discovery Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(27) One API ≠ One Tool

  • APIs can be large and multifunctional
  • Tools should be task-specific
  • AI rarely needs an entire API


Step #3: Dynamic Tool Discovery Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(28) GitHub API

  • GitHub API [https://github.com/github/rest-api-description]
    • 11MB
    • 320k lines
    • 738 paths
    • 1114 operations
    • 259 webhooks
  • GitHub MCP Server [https://github.com/github/github-mcp-server]
    • 19 toolsets (+3 remote)
    • 70 tools overall


Step #3: Dynamic Tool Discovery Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(29) API Microproducts

  • Traditional API products bundle endpoints into coarse offerings
  • With unknown use cases, it's better to decompose into fine-grained API microproducts
    • OpenAPI: Treat all operations on all endpoints as individual capabilities
    • AsyncAPI: Treat all messages on all channels as individual capabilities
    • GraphQL: Treat all queries and mutations as individual capabilities
  • Allows flexible combination of capabilities for any use case


Step #3: Dynamic Tool Discovery Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(30) Semantic Search with RAG

  • All capabilities indexed in a vector database
  • Queries resolved via semantic search (embeddings & similarity)
  • Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) assembles relevant operations
  • Depends heavily on high-quality descriptions


Step #3: Dynamic Tool Discovery Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(31) Dynamic Discovery ⇏ Ideal Tool Landscape

  • Discovery helps reduce tool overload
  • Agents still have to invent workflows from scratch
  • We need higher-level, business-aligned tools
  • Next: Step #4: Workflow-Based Tools [Step #4: Workflow-Based Tools (1)]

(33) Workflow-Based Tools



Step #4: Workflow-Based Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(34) Why Workflows Matter

  • Many tasks follow predictable, repeatable sequences
  • Agents shouldn't re-discover the same steps
  • Workflow tools reduce the number of tools agents must reason about
  • Higher-level tools = less context, less confusion, faster results


Step #4: Workflow-Based Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(35) Workflow Advantages

  • Predictability
  • Auditability
  • Compliance
  • Business alignment
  • Reduced need for AI
  • Energy/cost efficiency


Step #4: Workflow-Based Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(36) Observing AI to Discover Workflows

  • AI tries to solve tasks in its own way
  • Observing AI reveals workflow candidates
  • Workflows can be reviewed and replayed
  • Workflows are published as new APIs, usable beyond AI


Step #4: Workflow-Based Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(37) OAI Arazzo

  • Arazzo is an open workflow standard by OAI
  • It allows combining API interactions into workflows
  • Arazzo was designed for documentation, testing, and SDK generation
  • New versions will start incorporating AsyncAPI support


Step #4: Workflow-Based Tools Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(38) Workflow Tools ⇏ Safe Tool Use

  • Workflows help with AI productivity
  • Detecting/defining workflows is non-trivial
  • AI needs a safe space to work with tools
  • Next: Step #5: Safe Tool Practices [Step #5: Safe Tool Practices (1)]

Step #5: Safe Tool Practices Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(40) Safe Tool Practices



Step #5: Safe Tool Practices Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(41) Sandboxes for Workflow Discovery

  • Tool-creating agents can explore capabilities
  • Traces identify stable, reusable sequences
  • Recurring action patterns are workflow candidates
  • Reviewed sequences become reusable workflow


Step #5: Safe Tool Practices Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(42) Sandboxes for Safe AI Experimentation

  • Provide mocked or synthetic versions of real tools
  • Limit blast radius when testing AI applications
  • Validate AI application logic before production
  • On-demand safe spaces for subsets of the landscape
